question: Are misunderstandings in doctor–patient communication associated with non-adherence to prescribed treatment? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: They were all associated with potential or actual adverse outcomes such as non-adherence to treatment.
content.source_2: In a prospective, multicenter cohort of adults with type 2 diabetes, physician–patient misunderstandings were not predictive of medication non-adherence over 12 months (adjusted hazard ratio 1.01; 95% CI 0.90–1.13) after controlling for health literacy, cost, and regimen complexity.
content.source_3: Clarification of discrepancies in patients’ understanding during prescribing consultations was followed by a significant reduction in missed doses, indicating that uncorrected misunderstandings contribute to non-adherence.
content.source_4: A randomized trial of communication quality found no difference in adherence between visits with documented misunderstandings and those without (risk difference 0.3%, 95% CI −2.1 to 2.7), suggesting that misunderstandings do not lead to non-adherence when other factors are held constant.
